instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, no power
threads.message:
Hi.

Corrosion to the board, previous work by customer, been through UC

PPBUS = 8.62V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 1.2V


Oh, found the problem. I'll post this in case anyone else has a board like this.

Someone had removed <CAPACITOR>C7583</CAPACITOR> and torn the pad connecting to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>...
The connecting via comes from that pad through the very thin trace / pad of <CAPACITOR>C7583</CAPACITOR>. no idea if this is common but it may help someone if board has been fucked by customer.
